            I am an undergraduate student at Utah Valley University
            studying
            Bioinformatics
            while also obtaining a certificate in
            Geographic
            Information Systems (GIS). I was granted the
            NSF
            S-STEM scholarship my second year at UVU, allowing me to
            have a strong focus on research that interests me as an
            undergraduate. Currently, I am working on three research
            projects and was apart of one that is undergoing
            peer-review. My research interests deal with plant-microbe
            interactions, microbial biogeography and utilizing
            GIS/remote sensing techniques for ecology related questions.
            My hope is to continue my education after UVU and earn a PhD
            in a biology related field.

articles.title: NSF S-STEM Project
articles.description: *How do abiotic factors influence bacterial community assembly?*
articles.contents:
Contents
Abstract:
Presentations

Abstract:
The burning of fossil fuels has caused the Earth’s temperature to rise by roughly 1 degree Celsius compared to pre-industrial temperatures (IPCC, 2018; Lindsey & Dahlman, 2023). Consequently, droughts in the Southwestern United States are expected to increase in intensity and length (Cook et al., 2015). These disturbances will likely favor invasive plant species over native plant species (Turbelin & Catford, 2021). The goal of this research is to improve our understanding of the response patterns exhibited by plant communities and their associated microbes under projected climate change conditions to prepare and formulate strategies that effectively bolster the resilience of the ecosystem. In 2021, we conducted stress trials on plants collected in the field to determine the abiotic factors that significantly affect plant health. The following year we once again collected plant and soil samples in the field but with the goal of characterizing the bacterial community associated with different parts of the plants. We extracted and sequenced the DNA and performed a variety of analyses in Rstudio to characterize the bacterial community. Our next steps are to inoculate another round of plants in stress trials with bacterial species associated with plants that survived the original stress trials to determine if they are a significant part of plant survival under project climate change stressors.
